comments.body: Probably, but at the moment we have no entry for `PYTHONPATH` among the documented environment variables on https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/devel/reference_appendices/config.html.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +128,132 @@    {"invocation": {"module_args": {"data": "debugging_session"}}, "changed": false, "ping": "debugging_session"}

This subcommand takes care of setting the PYTHONPATH to use the exploded
:file:`debug_dir/ansible/module_utils` directory and invoking the script using
the arguments in the :file:`args` file.  You can continue to run it like this

comments.body: @samdoran Can we add some details about custom PYTHONPATH since collections might be installed at a different locations? Also, adding debbuging with Pycharm and VS code will be good to have but not a blocker.

> 
> @samdoran Can we add some details about custom PYTHONPATH since collections might be installed at a different locations? Also, adding debbuging with Pycharm and VS code will be good to have but not a blocker.

POV from documenter
Agree for the PYTHONPATH as it makes sense.
About adding information about different editors I'm a bit reluctant, I fear we will have to maintain that for all editors people want to use, and they may be out of date pretty quickly.  
However that's kind of information that may be interesting in a blog post on the Ansible blog for a particular editor.
Scratch the idea of Editor specific debugging steps. @bmillemathias Thanks.

> Scratch the idea of Editor specific debugging steps. @bmillemathias Thanks.

And I'm sure the bullhorn team would be more than happy to talk about this future blog post :)

@Akasurde I could mention that other debuggers should work with these methods as well. I assumed that was somewhat implied, but that's a bad assumption on my part. @nitzmahone did a Fest talk a while back on using the PyCharm remote debugger, so it is possible.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +96,100 @@
    This subcommand inserts the absolute path to ``debug_dir`` as the first item in ``sys.path`` and invokes the script using the arguments in the ``args`` file. You can continue to run the module like this until you understand the problem. Then you can copy the changes back into your real module file and test that the real module works via ``ansible`` or ``ansible-playbook``.
